name: How to Access and Work with DXI Service Gateways
title: How to Access and Work with DXI Service Gateways
body:
Overview

This article provides a detailed guide on accessing and working with the DXi Service Gateways. It includes information on the available service gateways, how to connect to them using SSH, and how to resolve common issues like the 'Unprotected Private File Key' error. Additionally, it explains how to navigate installation folders on the server.

  • 1. Available Service Gateways:
  • 2. Accessing the Service Gateways:
  • 3. Connecting to a Service Gateway:
  • 4. Navigating Installation Folders:
  • 5. Service Gateway Purpose and Usage
  • 6. Access Hurricane GUI for Hurricane configurations and logs
  • Troubleshooting

Information

1. Available Service Gateways:

There are four service gateways across different AWS clusters that you can access:

  • Prod-DE-03: servicegw.prod-de-03.customervoice360.com:65222 (AWS DE)
  • Prod-US-03: servicegw.prod-us-03.customervoice360.com:65222 (AWS USA)
  • Sandbox-DE-02: servicegw.sandbox-de-02.customervoice360.com:65222 (Sandbox Cluster)
  • BofA-US-01: servicegw.bofa-us-01.customervoice360.com:65222 (Bank of America Cluster)

2. Accessing the Service Gateways:

To gain access to the DXi Service Gateways, you must create an SSH public key. Follow the instructions provided in Creating SSH Public Key for DXI Service Gateways.

3. Connecting to a Service Gateway:

Once you have access, you can connect to a service gateway using any command line tool with the following command:

ssh -i ~/.ssh/<SSH_KEY> <EMAIL_USERNAME>@servicegw.prod-de-03.customervoice360.com -p 65222

Example:

ssh -i ~/.ssh/rsa_id rishi.singh@servicegw.prod-de-03.customervoice360.com -p 65222

Ref:

1. Location of private key file

2. email username

3. Complete service gateway name

4. Port number (6522 for all gateways)

5. Passphrase for the private key (set while creating the SSH key)

 

Note that you can further simplify the command to access the gateway as per the article: How to Setup SSH Config File for Quick Access to Service Gateways for DXI

4. Navigating Installation Folders:

All instances have their individual folders under /nfs/installations/. You can find the specific folder using the technical name of the installation:

cd /nfs/installations/<technical_name>

Example:

cd /nfs/installations/tx3689

To find the technical name of an installation, refer to its URL. For example, in https://tx3689.customervoice360.com, "tx3689" is the technical name. If an installation uses a customer domain, such as ww2.umfragecenter.de, use Globis to find the technical name and the correct cluster where the instance is hosted.

5. Service Gateway Purpose and Usage

A lot of the L2 tasks are tied to the service gateways, and they usually entail running some scripts and/or accessing the DB. Check the below resources:

  • Provisioning new DXI installations
  • How to Access and Work with MariaDB on DXI Service Gateways
  • Helperscripts

6. Access Hurricane GUI for Hurricane configurations and logs

Hurricane is hosted on an on Prem network, but that network has direct VPN connection with our Service Gateways. So once you login to service gateway, you should be able to reach Hurricane server via port forwarding and your local browser.

Steps for access:

  1. Connect to a service gateway using any command line tool with the following command:
    Note that this is the same command used for Gateway connection, but added an attribute for port forwarding: -L8085:10.250.10.142:8085 
    ssh -i ~/.ssh/<SSH_KEY> <EMAIL_USERNAME>@servicegw.prod-de-03.customervoice360.com -p 65222 -L8085:10.250.10.142:8085
    Example: 
    ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_xxx raymond.guirguis@servicegw.prod-de-03.customervoice360.com -p 65222 -L8085:10.250.10.142:8085
  2. Open your browser and navigate to: http://localhost:8085/ , this will automatically connect to Hurricane server GUI, since port forwarding is configured and active in the SSH command window.
  3. Login to server: Credentials on password state
  4. To access the logs, navigate to the Log Viewer and choose the Account, then download the log file

Troubleshooting

Resolving 'Unprotected Private File Key' Error:

If you encounter the 'Unprotected Private File Key' error, it is likely due to incorrect permissions on your private SSH key.

  • Windows:

    1. Right-click the key file and select "Properties."
    2. Navigate to the "Security" tab and remove all users except your own.
    3. Click "Advanced" and then "Disable Inheritance."

  • Linux/Mac:

    1. Navigate to the private key directory: cd ~/.ssh.
    2. Set the correct permissions: chmod 600 <KEY_NAME>.
    3. Verify the permissions: ls -l <KEY_NAME>. The output should show -rw------- for the key file.

After correcting the permissions, try connecting to the gateway again.

 

FAQ

1. What should I do if I don't have SSH access?

Follow the steps in the provided guide to create an SSH public key and request access.

2. What does the 'Unprotected Private File Key' error mean?

This error indicates that the permissions on your private SSH key are too open. Follow the steps under troubleshooting section to secure your key.

3. How can I find the technical name of an installation?

You can determine the technical name from the installation's URL or use Globis if the installation uses a customer domain.
